title: Conversion of Saul
shortSummary: Acts chapter 9 recounts the dramatic conversion of Saul, a fierce persecutor of Christians, who encounters the risen Jesus on the road to Damascus and becomes the apostle Paul. The chapter also highlights the early church's growth, Peter's healing miracles, and the expansion of the gospel through bold witness and divine intervention.
timeline: c. AD 33-36 - Early Church Growth and Saul's Conversion

keyCharacters.name: Saul (Paul)
keyCharacters.description: A zealous Pharisee who persecuted Christians but is dramatically converted by Jesus and becomes a bold apostle preaching Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Ananias
keyCharacters.description: A disciple in Damascus who obeys the Lord's command to restore Saul's sight and fill him with the Holy Spirit.

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of Jesus' apostles who performs miraculous healings in Lydda and Joppa, demonstrating the power of the risen Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Tabitha (Dorcas)
keyCharacters.description: A beloved disciple known for her good works and charity, whom Peter raises from the dead.

keyCharacters.name: Barnabas
keyCharacters.description: A respected disciple who advocates for Saul's acceptance among the Jerusalem believers.

definitions.definition: A person specially selected by God to carry out a divine mission, in this case, Saul being chosen to bear Christ's name before Gentiles and kings.
Metaphorical for blindness or spiritual blindness; here describing the temporary blindness Saul experienced before receiving sight.
An early term used to describe the Christian faith and followers of Jesus Christ.
Acts of charity or giving to the poor, exemplified by Tabitha's life of good works.

outline.heading: Saul’s Encounter with Jesus on the Road to Damascus
outline.description: Saul, intent on persecuting Christians, is confronted by a heavenly light and the voice of Jesus, leading to his temporary blindness and a profound spiritual transformation.

outline.heading: Ananias Restores Saul’s Sight and Spirit
outline.description: God commands Ananias to heal Saul, restoring his sight and filling him with the Holy Spirit, marking Saul’s full conversion and baptism.

outline.heading: Saul’s Early Ministry and Opposition in Damascus
outline.description: Saul immediately begins preaching Christ boldly, astonishing many and facing threats on his life, leading to his secret escape from Damascus.

outline.heading: Saul’s Acceptance and Ministry in Jerusalem
outline.description: Although initially met with suspicion, Saul is accepted by the apostles through Barnabas’ advocacy and continues to preach boldly until threats force him to move to Tarsus; meanwhile, the churches experience peace and growth.

outline.heading: Peter’s Miracles in Lydda and Joppa
outline.description: Peter heals Aeneas, restoring him to health, and raises Tabitha from the dead, resulting in many believing in the Lord and demonstrating the power of Christ working through the apostles.

outline.heading: Peter’s Stay with Simon the Tanner
outline.description: The chapter concludes noting Peter’s extended stay in Joppa with Simon the tanner, setting the stage for further ministry.

application: Be open to God's transformative work in your life, even if it challenges your current beliefs or plans.
Obediently respond to God's call, as Ananias did, even when it requires courage and faith.
Boldly proclaim the gospel, trusting God to use you despite opposition or fear.
Recognize the importance of fellowship and support within the Christian community, as seen in Barnabas’ role.

keyVerses.text: But the Lord said unto him, Go thy way: for he is a chosen vessel unto me, to bear my name before the Gentiles, and kings, and the children of Israel:
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's sovereign choice of Saul for a unique mission to spread the gospel widely.

keyVerses.text: And Ananias went his way, and entered into the house; and putting his hands on him said, Brother Saul, the Lord, even Jesus, that appeared unto thee in the way as thou camest, hath sent me, that thou mightest receive thy sight, and be filled with the Holy Ghost.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the obedience of Ananias and the divine empowerment of Saul through the Holy Spirit.

keyVerses.text: And straightway he preached Christ in the synagogues, that he is the Son of God.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates Saul’s immediate and bold proclamation of the gospel following his conversion.

keyVerses.text: But Peter put them all forth, and kneeled down, and prayed; and turning him to the body said, Tabitha, arise. And she opened her eyes: and when she saw Peter, she sat up.
keyVerses.significance: Shows the power of prayer and faith in Christ to bring life and hope even in death.
